question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authorization Bypass] Can an attacker exploit a race condition where queue.has_authority(ctx) passes during validation but authority is revoked before actuate() executes, allowing unauthorized config changes through the split validate/actuate pattern? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authorization Bypass] If queue.has_authority(ctx) only checks transaction sender but not the signer's role hierarchy, can a low-privilege operator escalate to set critical configs like fee_recipient by calling run() directly? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Access Control] Does the authority check at line 34 verify against a multi-sig or single authority? If single authority is compromised, can attacker drain all oracle fees by setting fee to max u64 and fee_recipient to their address? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Authorization Missing] Since run() is a public entry function callable by anyone who passes has_authority(), can an attacker front-run legitimate authority transactions to set malicious configs if they temporarily gain authority access? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authority Delegation] If queue.has_authority() allows delegated authority holders, can a revoked delegate still execute config changes if their transaction was submitted before revocation but processed after? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Time-of-check Time-of-use] Between validate() checking has_authority() at line 34 and actuate() modifying state at line 47, if authority changes in Queue due to parallel transaction, does this create a TOCTOU vulnerability allowing unauthorized updates? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Authority Revocation] If authority is revoked mid-transaction after validate() passes but before actuate() completes, will the config update still succeed, violating access control invariants? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Multi-sig Bypass] If the Queue authority check doesn't enforce minimum signature thresholds, can a single compromised key from a 3-of-5 multi-sig update critical oracle parameters unilaterally? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Version Mismatch] The version check at line 33 enforces EXPECTED_QUEUE_VERSION == 1, but if an upgraded Queue v2 exists with different config structure, can calling this action on v2 queues corrupt state or bypass new v2 validation logic? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Version Downgrade] If queue.version() can be manipulated or downgraded from v2 back to v1, can an attacker bypass stricter v2 validations by forcing execution through this v1 action module? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Constant: EXPECTED_QUEUE_VERSION] [Hardcoded Version] Since EXPECTED_QUEUE_VERSION is hardcoded to 1, when Queue upgrades to v2, will old transactions calling this action revert, causing DoS for legitimate config updates until this module is also upgraded? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Version Check Order] Version check happens before authority check; if an attacker crafts a v2 queue mimicking v1 structure, could they bypass version validation and exploit authority check differences between versions? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Migration Path] During queue migration from v1 to v2, if both versions co-exist, can an attacker use this v1 action to update a partially-migrated v2 queue, causing inconsistent state across versions? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Integer Overflow] min_attestations is validated to be > 0 at line 35, but no upper bound check exists. Can setting min_attestations to u64::MAX cause overflow in downstream oracle aggregation logic that sums attestations? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [DoS via Excessive Attestations] Since min_attestations > 0 is the only check at line 35, can malicious authority set min_attestations to 1000000, making oracle updates impossible if only 10 oracles exist, effectively DoS'ing the entire queue? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Attestation Reduction Attack] If min_attestations is reduced from 10 to 1 via line 47's set_configs(), can an attacker colluding with a single oracle now manipulate price feeds that previously required 10-of-N consensus? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Zero-to-One Edge] While line 35 rejects min_attestations == 0, setting it to 1 may violate business logic requiring minimum 3 attestations for security. Is there missing lower bound validation beyond just > 0? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Dynamic Attestation Change] Can rapid min_attestations changes (10→1→10) in consecutive transactions cause oracle submissions with intermediate values to become invalid retroactively, locking user funds awaiting oracle confirmations? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Attestation Mismatch] If in-flight oracle update transactions reference old min_attestations but new config at line 51 has different min_attestations, will these updates fail or use stale requirements, creating oracle data inconsistency? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Attestation Type] min_attestations is u64 but typical oracle counts are small (< 100). Can overflow occur if min_attestations is used in multiplication operations (e.g., min_attestations * oracle_count) without checked_mul? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Time Manipulation] oracle_validity_length_ms only checks > 0 at line 36, no upper bound. Can setting to u64::MAX (584 million years) make stale oracle data permanently valid, allowing attackers to use manipulated historical prices indefinitely? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [DoS via Zero Validity] While line 36 prevents exactly 0, can setting oracle_validity_length_ms to 1 millisecond cause all oracle data to expire immediately, DoS'ing price feed consumers relying on valid oracle data? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Validity Window Attack] If oracle_validity_length_ms is reduced from 3600000ms (1h) to 1000ms (1s) via line 52, do existing cached oracle values immediately become invalid, forcing re-submission and enabling frontrunning attacks during the update window? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Timestamp Overflow] If downstream logic adds oracle_validity_length_ms to current timestamp for expiry checks, can setting oracle_validity_length_ms close to u64::MAX cause timestamp + oracle_validity_length_ms to overflow, wrapping to small values and marking fresh data as expired? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/queue/queue_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Validity Expansion Attack] Can malicious authority extend oracle_validity_length_ms from 1 hour to 30 days, then manipulate prices during low-liquidity periods, with manipulated prices remaining valid for a month to drain vaults? (Critical)
